solution_line_template: Starting with ${initial_money}, he paid ${colin_payment} to Colin, leaving him with ${initial_money}-${colin_payment}=$<<{initial_money}-{colin_payment}={after_colin}>>{after_colin}.
Thus, he paid ${helen_payment} to Helen, leaving him with ${after_colin}-${helen_payment}=$<<{after_colin}-{helen_payment}={after_helen}>>{after_helen}.
Half as much to Benedict as he had paid to Helen is ${helen_payment}/{benedict_divisor}=$<<{helen_payment}/{benedict_divisor}={benedict_payment}>>{benedict_payment}.
Thus, he paid ${benedict_payment} to Benedict, leaving him with ${after_helen}-${benedict_payment}=${after_benedict} after paying off all debts.
